title: 112_hr416
content: The "Health Insurance Rate Review Act" is aimed at protecting consumers from excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates. The "Health Insurance Rate Review Act" aims to protect consumers from excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates by allowing states to impose additional requirements on health insurance issuers for rate review processes. The Secretary consults with the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and consumer groups in the rate review process. The Secretary determines which states' insurance commissioner or regulator will undertake corrective actions as a condition for receiving grants. The Secretary also decides which states will have the corrective actions undertaken by the Secretary. The Secretary collaborates with state insurance commissioners to address excessive, unjustified, or discriminatory rates through corrective actions. This is done in states where the Secretary deems necessary due to inadequate state preparation or action. The Secretary works with state insurance commissioners to address potentially excessive, unjustified, or unfairly discriminatory rates by denying, modifying, or requiring rebates to consumers. Amendments clarify regulatory authority regarding rate adjustments. Amendments to address discriminatory rate adjustments and clarify regulatory authority regarding rate adjustments. Amendments to Title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act to address discriminatory rate adjustments and clarify regulatory authority regarding rate adjustments. Amendments to Title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act include inserting references to section 2794 in various subsections to address discriminatory rate adjustments and clarify regulatory authority. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of enactment of this Act.
